case_vignette: A 5-year-old male with a past medical history of well-controlled eczema presents with light colored patches on the face and forearms noticed by the patient's parents a few days ago. Parents deny any trauma to the sites or any new topical products. Patient denies any pruritus or pain at the affected areas. Examination of the face reveals poorly demarcated ovoid hypopigmented patches on the cheeks and forearms.
question: What is the final diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have light-colored patches on my face and forearms.
How long have you noticed these patches for?
They were noticed a few days ago.
Do these patches feel itchy or painful?
No, they are neither itchy nor painful.
Have there been any recent changes to your personal care products, detergents, or exposure to new substances?
No, there haven't been any changes to personal care products or exposure to new substances.
Do you or anyone in your family have a history of skin conditions or autoimmune diseases?
I have a history of well-controlled eczema.
Are the patches lighter than your normal skin tone or red and inflamed?
The patches are lighter than my normal skin tone.
Final Diagnosis: Vitiligo
